gridDisplay.subtitle: Sky Father - The primordial masculine principle
gridDisplay.title: Greek Mythology

description: Uranus (Greek: Ouranos, meaning 'sky' or 'heaven') is the primordial Greek god of the sky, the first divine ruler of the cosmos, and the personification of the heavens. According to Hesiod's Theogony, Uranus was born from Gaia (Earth) alone, then became her consort. Together they produced the Titans (including Cronus, Rhea, Oceanus, and Hyperion), the Cyclopes, and the Hecatoncheires (Hundred-Handed Ones). Uranus hated his monstrous children and imprisoned them within Gaia, causing her great pain. Gaia conspired with Cronus, who castrated his father with an adamantine sickle, ending Uranus's reign. From the blood that fell on Earth sprang the Giants, the Erinyes (Furies), and the Meliae (ash tree nymphs); from the severed genitals cast into the sea was born Aphrodite. Uranus's castration represents the separation of sky and earth, a common creation motif. As the starry sky, Uranus remained ever-present but powerless, replaced by the rule of the Titans and later the Olympians.

parents.mother: Gaia (Earth) - born parthenogenetically or from Chaos

sources.passage: Lines 126-210 - Birth of Uranus and his castration
